WRITING.TEXT: Good call. Something to get it back into the conversation would definitely be a need to get it into Network's (or online's) minds.

I had no idea Dead Stockwell had a stroke. That's so sad to hear, but I'm glad he's apparently doing well.
That's been the idea put out there for a while, to have his daughter go looking for him. I'd be totally down for that, definitely.

Fair enough. There are levels to it, though, you know? Where you get something that's pretty cult, but people talk about it frequently enough. This show doesn't seem to have had that staying power. I could be way off base, though.

WRITING.TITLE: After this year's upfronts I have one question: Is there even a DISCUSSION about bringing back Quantum Leap?
WRITING.TEXT:
Roseanne, Will and Grace, Twin Peaks, Gilmore Girls, Fuller House, Girl Meets World, etc., etc., etc. Of all of the shows that are coming back or have come back as continuations, why *not* Quantum Leap? This is just a rant, basically, but seriously are there any viable rumors at all that this might be happening? In my life I've been burned by failed film scripts too many times to get my hopes up, but part of me still believes.
There's no reason not to do it, in my mind, Sci-Fi and time travel are still obviously popular, the demand is there, I'd think, but maybe that's where I'm over-valuing the show. In my mind it's one of the biggest cult classics ever, but in a quick poll around work, it seems like most people here never watched it.
If they did it, would you rather it be a continuation with Bakula, or a new character that eventually runs into him, as I've seen other people suggest could be a decent plot? With Twin Peaks coming back, I've become more convinced that with enough love and support from original cast/crew, this is something that could and should happen, but I wouldn't want it without Bakula. Maybe a spin-off could be fun, though.
Thus why I was wondering if there were elements to this I didn't understand. Thanks!

That's what I don't understand. Did I miss something, or are people just choosing to ignore this part in light of all of the bullshit that happened to him in the last couple of weeks (plus under the Bush admin)?

*Lost to Rumble before the streak even started because Rumble was able to hit him with one of his bombs after the round should've been over thanks to a faulty clock.
/justsayin'
There's still time.
I was right there with you.

My greatest hottake is still my greatest shame:
"UFC 208 will be ALL finishes. This card is going to be legendary." Or something along those lines. Constantly, for two weeks leading up to the fight.
The texts and comments I got at work over the next week were brutal, haha.
Has any U.S. president?
I did it like once where it actually worked, so you're not necessarily wrong here.
That scene in the Ray Liotta film is fantastic.
How dare you speak ill of UFC 211 like that.

IMO, they expected one or two of about four or five scenarios and saw $$$:
1) Ronda beats Nunes Gets a shot at being a 2-division champ
2) Ronda beats Nunes, Holly beats GDR Ronda gets a shot at being a 2-division champ AND they get that highly sought-after rematch.
3) Ronda beats Nunes, Holly beats GDR, Ronda beats Holly Ronda is 2-division champ AND we get to see her fight Cyborg, finally.
4) Ronda beats Nunes, Holly beats GDR, Holly beats Ronda Holly Hype Train is back in motion, Holly then either goes back to Bantamweight to try HER luck at 2-division champ status or
5) Ronda beats Nunes, Holly beats GDR, Holly beats Ronda Holly Hype Train is back in motion, Holly fights Cyborg.
All of these are big money scenarios for the UFC and even if the first part doesn't happen and you get no scenarios with Ronda, you STILL get the last scenario, which is Holly v Cyborg...until, of course, everything went to shit and:
1) Ronda lost 2) Holly lost 3) Cyborg popped
Literally everything that could've gone wrong DID. Now, even with Cyborg already pretty much back in you have NO story-lines remaining. Who cares if Cyborg fights GDR? Nunes has no interest in going to Featherweight. It's just not there.
The best thing that could've happened is if NYSAC had overturned Holly's loss, the thing went to a no contest and we pretended it never happened.

AJ is in my all-time favorites, probably a top 3 favorite fighter of mine, but I wouldn't call him a GOAT.
He's the P4P top shoulda coulda woulda GOAT though. If he had been more interested in winning than not getting knocked out, but that never seemed to be his thing. At this point, I think we all know he gives his back up if he's afraid of taking too much damage. Take away that aspect, and have him not waste half of his career at WW and you're probably talking about the alternate reality where he's the GOAT.

Thank you so much for your help! This is all making the decision-making process a lot easier.
I do have a short torso, haha. Trying one of the bikes this weekend was amusing to the people helping me because every time we'd get my legs right it would make my arms too short for the bike. Eventually he told me he'd just adjust the bike manually for me if I bought it, so that the handlebars would fit.
Awesome, thank you so much! You've been a ton of help, and I really appreciate it.

It's not really that you're putting me off of it so much is that it doesn't sound like the bike I want is something that I should get, hence not really wanting the bike, in that case.
I will be riding it on trails. I will be riding it at a local park with gravel bike paths. I *might* be riding it to work. I don't know about the last part. I was not under the impression that two of the bikes I were looking at were mountain bikes, I was told they were hybrids. It's possible I misunderstood
If I didn't get the brakes and went with this bike instead, what about it would not be suiting what I've described?
http://www.cannondale.com/en/USA/Bike/ProductDetail?Id=6fb60a09-4fcf-452b-a690-8117adb35039

I'm not really looking for a mountain bike, though. I initially went in for a hybrid bike, the different reps at the different stores I went to selected these. I know the first one is a mountain bike, but aren't the other two hybrids?

Ah that's disappointing to hear. The three bikes were selected by three different reps at three different bike shops, so I was hoping one of them would do the trick for what I was looking for.
I'll be honest, having time to think it over, I'm getting cold feet on the whole purchase anyways. Part of the reason I was so focused on disc breaks is that I'm VERY frightened of riding it on the streets. Not sure I'll end up really doing much of anything with it once my foot heels, as a result.
Thanks for your help!

Still looking for some advice on my first bike. Looks like I maybe posted in last week's thread a little too late for anyone to see, but to save you all a wall of text, the bikes I'm looking at, I described in detail over at r/whichbike. [This is a link to the post.](https://www.reddit.com/r/whichbike/comments/6352lh/first_bike_three_options/)
Thanks so much for any help!

Looking at getting my first bike. I've posted over at r/whichbike, but if anyone has advice as well, I'd really appreciate the help. C/P of my post there:
Hi everyone,
I'm looking to get a bike to keep myself active while recovering from tendinitis after a long race. I figured, though, since I recently started a job closer to home, maybe I could also start commuting to work. Fitness is first and foremost on my priorities list, and after some shopping around today I came down to three options and I'd appreciate some advice:
1) Haro Flightline Two (2014) -$480 This is the bike I want most, and a strong part of that is I like the paint job on it, so I'm trying to ignore that aspect. This option also has financing available, so I'm freed up to spend more money on things I need right away (lights, lock, pump, etc.) and could maybe get the revolights, which would make me feel a lot safer commuting.
2) Cannondale Quick 5 with disk brakes - $600+ (can't remember exactly.) This is the most expensive option, but the store I found it at offers lifetime free tuneups. The one thing I'm concerned about is reviews saying it's not great offroad.
3) Liv Bliss 2 - $380 And finally, I found this bike, which is the cheapest option, seems like a good value, and would allow me to buy the bike outright, and any other accessories I might need, but is the bike I'm least passionate about.
Your level of experience with cycling - Road bikes a lot as a kid, and commuted during college, but that was only about 1 mile each way on sidewalks.
What's your price range, and have you considered second hand? - $300-$700 (but I don't WANT to spend $700 because of tax, that's like the actually upper limit all included). I looked around second hand a bit, but I am fairly short and finding a bike that I want in my size has proved difficult.
What's your intention with the bike - commuting, fitness, touring, sport, etc? - Fitness first and foremost, then potentially commuting. I have very little interest in touring right now (but maybe sometime down the road I'll add it to the group of activities I like to do. I'm very scared of dying on a bike, so it's unlikely I'll tempt fate to that degree).
How far will you be riding, and how often? - For now, I'd like to ride for about an hour four days out of the week. I'd like that to be about 12 miles, but we'll see about that/where I can find to ride it)
Riding conditions: roads, pavement, trails, single-track, off-road? Flat or hilly? Traffic and weather. - Pavement most of the time and road. I'm going to take it on trails eventually, though. I live in SOCal, so trails are hilly as are the streets.

Oh I'm sorry. I was on mobile and really stressing out about trying to make a decision when I found this sub, and I just barreled in head first. I'll add the answers to the post, but here you are:
Your level of experience with cycling - Road bikes a lot as a kid, and commuted during college, but that was only about 1 mile each way on sidewalks.
What's your price range, and have you considered second hand? - $300-$700 (but I don't WANT to spend $700 because of tax, that's like the actually upper limit all included). I looked around second hand a bit, but I am fairly short and finding a bike that I want in my size has proved difficult.
What's your intention with the bike - commuting, fitness, touring, sport, etc? - Fitness first and foremost, then potentially commuting. I have very little interest in touring right now (but maybe sometime down the road I'll add it to the group of activities I like to do. I'm very scared of dying on a bike, so it's unlikely I'll tempt fate to that degree).
How far will you be riding, and how often? - For now, I'd like to ride for about an hour four days out of the week. I'd like that to be about 12 miles, but we'll see about that/where I can find to ride it)
Riding conditions: roads, pavement, trails, single-track, off-road? Flat or hilly? Traffic and weather. - Pavement most of the time and road. I'm going to take it on trails eventually, though. I live in SOCal, so trails are hilly as are the streets.

WRITING.TITLE: First bike - three options.
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi everyone,
I'm looking to get a bike to keep myself active while recovering from tendinitis after a long race. I figured, though, since I recently started a job closer to home, maybe I could also start commuting to work. Fitness is first and foremost on my priorities list, and after some shopping around today I came down to three options and I'd appreciate some advice:
1) Haro Flightline Two (2014) -$480 This is the bike I want most, and a strong part of that is I like the paint job on it, so I'm trying to ignore that aspect. This option also has financing available, so I'm freed up to spend more money on things I need right away (lights, lock, pump, etc.) and could maybe get the revolights, which would make me feel a lot safer commuting.
2) Cannondale Quick 5 with disk brakes - $600+ (can't remember exactly.) This is the most expensive option, but the store I found it at offers lifetime free tuneups. The one thing I'm concerned about is reviews saying it's not great offroad.
3) Liv Bliss 2 - $380 And finally, I found this bike, which is the cheapest option, seems like a good value, and would allow me to buy the bike outright, and any other accessories I might need, but is the bike I'm least passionate about.
So, Internet, what say you?
EDIT: Sorry, I didn't see the questions in the sidebar. More info:
Your level of experience with cycling - Road bikes a lot as a kid, and commuted during college, but that was only about 1 mile each way on sidewalks.
What's your price range, and have you considered second hand? - $300-$700 (but I don't WANT to spend $700 because of tax, that's like the actually upper limit all included). I looked around second hand a bit, but I am fairly short and finding a bike that I want in my size has proved difficult.
What's your intention with the bike - commuting, fitness, touring, sport, etc? - Fitness first and foremost, then potentially commuting. I have very little interest in touring right now (but maybe sometime down the road I'll add it to the group of activities I like to do. I'm very scared of dying on a bike, so it's unlikely I'll tempt fate to that degree).
How far will you be riding, and how often? - For now, I'd like to ride for about an hour four days out of the week. I'd like that to be about 12 miles, but we'll see about that/where I can find to ride it)
Riding conditions: roads, pavement, trails, single-track, off-road? Flat or hilly? Traffic and weather. - Pavement most of the time and road. I'm going to take it on trails eventually, though. I live in SOCal, so trails are hilly as are the streets.
This is my life, basically all day every day if I DARE to get off the couch/bed for a second.

Been using this for over a year now. Really happy with it, even though it can occasionally be just a touch buggy. Still using this routine, perfect time and amount of lifting for me:

I was there. Screaming and laughing and jumping in circles. I couldn't stop for about five minutes. And I STILL laugh every time I think about it.

Oh I disagree. If I'd known Glover's arm was hurt, that've been a different story, but I expected Miller/Poirier to be fight of the night (and I was right about that at least), Glover to finish by major knockout, Souza to win by a slick sub (right there again as well), and then I'm not about to miss Silva, though I expected more out of that fight. As for the main event, while I think a Women's Featherweight division is stupid as hell, I very much expected that fight to be a killer. Didn't expect Holly to fight so defensively.
So in my mind you were looking at: Fight of the Night
Knockout
Sub
Knockout/Sub I actually specifically called a triangle and got really excited when Anderson started going for one at the end, but it didn't happen
Two-way beat down
Almost none of that came to fruition, of course. Ahhh well.

Nah, definitely didn't turn me off the UFC.
I had it in my head that the way the matchups were shaping up, the main card would be all badass finishes. I was really, REALLY convinced it was going to be fantastic. My husband wasn't feeling well and didn't want to go out, but we both wanted to see if I was right, so he was like, 'ah fuck it, let's just buy it.' So we did and...well...I'm sorry to you all for making UFC 208 so boring, haha.
That was the first PPV I've ever bought. I don't know if I'll ever do it again. Safer to just go out and get a nice dinner/drinks and watch it at a bar.
Haha, that's fantastic. Ahhh well.
I've tried to go back and watch a bit more, but haven't seen much. I'll try to check these out.

This is all fantastic.
I mean, the guy's name is literally what Japanese speakers use to say they're feeling well/in good spirits, so it's nice to see someone living their namesake so thoroughly.
(By the way, what an odd intro he has to his Wikipedia article:
Genki Sudo is a Japanese singer, composer,[2] choreographer, actor, professional calligrapher and author. He is the producer, director, and former lead vocalist of the music group World Order,[3] which is known for their techno music style and highly synchronised robotic choreography. Sudo is a retired mixed martial artist and a kickboxer who, until December 31, 2006 competed in the Japanese fighting organization HERO'S and before that, the Ultimate Fighting Championship and Pancrase.
I thought I was on the wrong wiki page at first because it took three sentences to get to him being an MMA fighter, haha. )

It's true, though, he did seem to have Tony in a bit of trouble, even that early on.
Glad someone's mentioning this. I'm still angry and bitter to this day. And people keep lauding him for that win, too.
Then use the other functionality of the Fitbit and pay attention to your calorie budget. There's way more to the ~$100 piece of tech you bought besides being a step counter.

People are kinda ignoring some of the other aspects of fitbit, such as the calorie allowance / budget. Telling it how much you want to lose per week will have it tell you how much to eat per day. Using it correctly, doing the bare minimum means you eat the bare minimum, hence I'm always trying to go past my goals, or make my goals higher.

I liked the idea of the book more than the book itself, and I didn't even realize what was so wonderful about it until it was over, which I found unfortunate.
To write a book around lost photos is brilliant. I wish I had known that was how it had come to be going in, because for the most part, I found the book kinda tedious and meandering. It's clearly the opening to a series, which I was hoping it wouldn't be. One thing I don't like about this book club is the tendency to nominate books that are part of a series, because now I need to read the rest of the series!!! _ (mostly kidding)
